headline: JPMorgan earnings, December CPI, Trump comments: What to Watch
summary: Market Domination Overtime Host Brooke DiPalma previews several of the biggest stories to come tomorrow, Tuesday, January 13, including quarterly earnings results from JPMorgan Chase (JPM), the Bank of NY Mellon (BK), and Delta Air Lines (DAL); the latest inflation reading from December's Consumer Price Index (CPI) report; new home sales data; and President Trump's speech at the Detroit Economic Club at 2 P.M. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

headline: Fed Speakers, Bank Earnings, Inflation Data: What to Watch This Week
summary: Key economic data are due this week, including two inflation readings. The U.S.'s largest banks are also scheduled to report earnings, starting with JPMorgan Chase. Later this week, results from Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, known as TSMC, will pulse-check the AI boom.

headline: Stock Futures Fall From Record Highs as Markets Await Earnings and Inflation Data
summary: Stocks looked set to fall on Tuesday, with investors reluctant to make any major moves ahead of the start of fourth-quarter earnings season and a consumer price index inflation print.  The Dow and S&P 500 both extended their record-breaking runs on Monday, hitting new closing highs as investors managed to shake off the worst of their worries about the independence of the Federal Reserve.  The dip in futures probably reflects some apprehension ahead of the December CPI report, which will help decide if the Fed has scope to cut interest rates.

headline: Delta Air Lines Beat Earnings Expectations. Why the Stock Is Tumbling.
summary: Delta Air Lines  stock was falling ahead of the open Tuesday after the airline beat earnings expectations but issued disappointing guidance for the year ahead.  Delta reported adjusted earnings per share of $1.55 on revenue of $14.6 billion in the fourth quarter.  Investors may be focusing on Delta‚Äôs full-year guidance for 2026, which came in lower than Wall Street‚Äôs view.

headline: Delta Air Lines Orders up to 60 Boeing 787 Dreamliners to Grow, Modernize Widebody Fleet
summary: Boeing (NYSE: BA) and Delta Air Lines today announced the U.S. carrier placed its first direct order for up to 60 787 Dreamliners to support long-haul international growth and renew the airline's widebody fleet. Delta's purchase of 30 787-10 jets ‚Äì with opportunity for up to 30 more of the largest 787 variant ‚Äì will enable the airline's expansion and modernization plans on high-demand transatlantic and South American routes.

headline: Delta‚Äôs (NYSE:DAL) Q4 CY2025: Beats On Revenue But Stock Drops
summary: Global airline Delta Air Lines (NYSE:DAL) announced better-than-expected revenue in Q4 CY2025, with sales up 2.9% year on year to $16 billion. Guidance for next quarter‚Äôs revenue was better than expected at $14.88 billion at the midpoint, 1.1% above analysts‚Äô estimates. Its GAAP profit of $1.86 per share was 18.7% above analysts‚Äô consensus estimates.

Guidance for next quarter‚Äôs revenue was better than expected at $14.88 billion at the midpoint, 1.1% above analysts‚Äô estimates. headline: Wall Street ticks lower as first earnings reports trickle in ahead of latest US inflation data
summary: U.S. markets inched slightly lower before the opening bell Tuesday as investors pore over the first big earnings reports before turning their attention to the government's latest inflation data.  JPMorgan shares rose less than 1% after the New York investment bank beat Wall Street's revenue and profit forecasts on a strong performance in markets and growth in its consumer banking division.  Delta Air Lines, which just barely beat Wall Street's fourth-quarter targets, tumbled 5% after its 2026 guidance disappointed investors.

content.title: Wall Street ticks lower as first earnings reports trickle in ahead of latest US inflation data
content.summary: U.S. markets inched slightly lower before the opening bell Tuesday as investors pore over the first big earnings reports before turning their attention to the government's latest inflation data.  JPMorgan shares rose less than 1% after the New York investment bank beat Wall Street's revenue and profit forecasts on a strong performance in markets and growth in its consumer banking division.  Delta Air Lines, which just barely beat Wall Street's fourth-quarter targets, tumbled 5% after its 2026 guidance disappointed investors.

thumbnail.caption: Trader Robert Finnerty Jr., foreground, works with colleagues on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Monday, Jan. 12, 2026. (AP Photo/Richard Drew)

headline: Delta isn't 'perpetual motion machine' despite 2026 growth promises
summary: Delta Air Lines (DAL) stock is stumbling in Tuesday's pre-market trading after the airline operator reported fourth quarter earnings that beat estimates, while revenue fell just shy of expectations. Additionally, Delta's full-year earnings forecast for 2026 proved to be more conservative than what Wall Street had projected. Morningstar equity analyst in aerospace and defense Nicolas Owens examines Delta's promises of growth, to which he says that the current travel market "isn't a perpetual motion machine." To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

content.title: Delta isn't 'perpetual motion machine' despite 2026 growth promises
content.description:
Delta Air Lines (DAL) stock is stumbling in Tuesday's pre-market trading after the airline operator reported fourth quarter earnings that beat estimates, while revenue fell just shy of expectations. Additionally, Delta's full-year earnings forecast for 2026 proved to be more conservative than what Wall Street had projected.

Morningstar equity analyst in aerospace and defense Nicolas Owens examines Delta's promises of growth, to which he says that the current travel market "isn't a perpetual motion machine."

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more¬†Morning Brief.

headline: Wall Street hangs near its records as JPMorgan Chase and Delta Air Lines kick off earnings season
summary: U.S. stock indexes are holding near their records on Tuesday following the latest update on inflation, one that could keep the door open for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates further later this year.  Yields also eased in the bond market after the inflation data strengthened expectations that the Fed may be able to cut its main interest rate at least twice in 2026 to shore up the job market.  Traders still see little chance of a move at the Fed‚Äôs next meeting later this month, even if Tuesday‚Äôs inflation report raised the probability of a cut slightly to 5%, according to data from CME Group.

content.title: Wall Street hangs near its records as JPMorgan Chase and Delta Air Lines kick off earnings season
content.summary: U.S. stock indexes are holding near their records on Tuesday following the latest update on inflation, one that could keep the door open for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates further later this year.  Yields also eased in the bond market after the inflation data strengthened expectations that the Fed may be able to cut its main interest rate at least twice in 2026 to shore up the job market.  Traders still see little chance of a move at the Fed‚Äôs next meeting later this month, even if Tuesday‚Äôs inflation report raised the probability of a cut slightly to 5%, according to data from CME Group.

thumbnail.caption: Trader Robert Finnerty Jr., foreground, works with colleagues on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Monday, Jan. 12, 2026. (AP Photo/Richard Drew)
